div.p: I had already read the World Set Free in the E.R. and reread it in the copy you kindly sent me. It has interested me quite enormously. You know that the utopian part of your novels, + certain biographical details [?] thereunto (the splendid “conversion” of the passionate friendship man by the lake of Geneva, + the whole tremendous tragedy of the man spendthrift wife in Marriage) always seem to me your real (excuse the beastly word) cannibalism to one’s - at least my - happiness. All Karenin’s views about not fussing so much about sex + sex differences of course made my heart rejoice beyond words. I should like to have talks with you about it all. But I now recognize (what my blind-bat selfishness hid for some years) that your part is to see these things vividly, make us see + feel them + their turn to thinking + feeling some other side of things, + that it is therefore unfair + boring to expect you to talk about what you have delivered your soul of in writing.

If however your experience of my hopeless disputativeness does not disincline you, I could come to see you + Mrs Wells for a couple of days in July. And more precisely on the 18th July, when I shall be going to Suffolk; or else on the 28th when I shall leave it. I wonder whether Mrs Wells would let me have a postcard about it? I shall be in England a very short time + have to fit in my plans like a bad mosaic - I shall be in London the first fortnight in July, so perhaps we might meet there.
What funny stuff Louis Norbert must seem to you if you have dipped into it. Now I wish I could write about the things that really matter to me!
Well - let me know whether we may meet,
div.closer: My love to Mrs Wells Yours truly
